articles.headline: Death Penalty for Rampage at Fort Hood
articles.snippet: Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan never denied shooting more than 40 people at the Texas military base, and offered little in the way of defense.
articles.abstract: Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan never denied shooting more than 40 people at the Texas military base, and offered little in the way of defense.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist who admitted to killing 13 unarmed people at Fort Hood nearly four years ago, was sentenced to death by lethal injection by a jury on Wednesday, becoming one of only a handful of men on military death row.

articles.headline: Saluting a Dream, and Adapting It for a New Era
articles.snippet: President Obama stepped into the space where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. once spoke and summoned his iconic dream of a colorblind society in a celebration of a half-century of progress.
articles.abstract: President Obama stepped into the space where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. once spoke and summoned his iconic dream of a colorblind society in a celebration of a half-century of progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama stepped into the space on Wednesday where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. once stood, summoning his iconic dream of a colorblind society in a celebration of a half-century of progress and a call to arms for the next generation.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: As Renters Move In, Some Homeowners Fret
articles.snippet: Some homeowners worry about the changing makeup of their neighborhoods, as they fill with tenants who have little investment in the area.
articles.abstract: Some homeowners worry about the changing makeup of their neighborhoods, as they fill with tenants who have little investment in the area.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Beneath the spreading shade tree in Laura Holcomb’s front yard, there are some 70 varieties of hosta, stands of elephant ear and a Japanese maple. For the 17 years she has owned the brick house on Rose Trail Drive in the Hillshire subdivision, Ms. Holcomb has devoted herself to her home and garden.

articles.headline: All Around the World in Just Two Film Roles
articles.snippet: For actors like Daniel Brühl, the new globalism in film has brought opportunities that were almost unimaginable in the middle of the last decade.
articles.abstract: For actors like Daniel Brühl, the new globalism in film has brought opportunities that were almost unimaginable in the middle of the last decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The actor Daniel Brühl, who is Spanish and German, will soon have a global moment in Toronto.

articles.headline: After a Recession in Portugal, the Tiny Green Fruits of Success
articles.snippet: Recent data suggest that the country is indeed hitting its export stride, but the balance sheets of the nation’s banks could weigh on the fragile economic comeback.
articles.abstract: Recent data suggest that the country is indeed hitting its export stride, but the balance sheets of the nation’s banks could weigh on the fragile economic comeback.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOURA, Portugal — Portugal is finding that increasing exports is the way to pull its economy out of a recession.

articles.headline: House Bid to Undo Dialysis Cuts Shows Lobbyists’ Muscle
articles.snippet: Many members of Congress who voted to eliminate over $500 million a year in federal government waste now want to reverse that move, demonstrating lobbyists’ muscle.
articles.abstract: Many members of Congress who voted to eliminate over $500 million a year in federal government waste now want to reverse that move, demonstrating lobbyists’ muscle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Eight months ago, Congress ordered the Obama administration to eliminate a stark example of federal government waste: more than $500 million a year in excessive drug payments being sent to dialysis clinics nationwide.

articles.headline: U.S. Facing Test on Data to Back Action on Syria
articles.snippet: The Obama administration says the information it will make public will show proof of a large-scale chemical attack by Syrian forces.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration says the information it will make public will show proof of a large-scale chemical attack by Syrian forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The evidence of a massacre is undeniable: the bodies of the dead lined up on hospital floors, those of the living convulsing and writhing in pain and a declaration from a respected international aid group that thousands of Syrians were gassed with chemical weapons last week.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Amid Chaos, Israelis Take a Stoic View
articles.snippet: Many Israelis said this summer had spawned an “I-told-you-so” sensibility among those skeptical about the Arab Spring, and a sense of relief that for now, the problems are elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Many Israelis said this summer had spawned an “I-told-you-so” sensibility among those skeptical about the Arab Spring, and a sense of relief that for now, the problems are elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The retired men who parse politics on Monday mornings over cappuccino at the Hadar Mall here have watched all manner of war, uprisings and chaos. To them, the chemical attacks to the north in Syria and the military crackdown against Islamists to the south in Egypt are almost comforting, a confirmation of a common Israeli view that their Arab neighbors are unready for democracy, while also offering a diversion from their own conflict with the Palestinians.

articles.headline: In Talks With Vodafone, Verizon Banks on Wireless Future
articles.snippet: If talks to buy out Vodafone’s stake in Verizon Wireless are successful, Verizon would be able to shift from receiving dividends to being able to fully incorporate all of its profit.
articles.abstract: If talks to buy out Vodafone’s stake in Verizon Wireless are successful, Verizon would be able to shift from receiving dividends to being able to fully incorporate all of its profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:27 p.m. |  With nearly 100 million Americans using Verizon Wireless for their cellphone service, it may not seem obvious that almost half of Verizon is owned by a company overseas.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Mark Scott
